titlestmt.subtitle: An Inventory of the Collection, 1908-1915 and undated, at the Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library
titlestmt.author: Abel Ramirez

titlepage.titleproper: Inventory for the City of Post, Texas Blueprint Collection, 1908-1915 and undated
titlepage.author: Abel Ramirez

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: City of Post, Texas, Blueprint Collection, 1908-1915 and undated
did.abstract: This collection consists blueprints of various structures in the City of Post, Texas.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, Texas Tech University

bioghist.head: Biographical Sketch
bioghist.p: The county seat of Garza County, Post was established as a town in 1907 when cereal magnate Charles William Post bought 200,000 acres of ranch land and created the Double U Company. The company was responsible for the construction of the town and landscaping, as well as renting and selling farm land and buildings.
The Handbook of Texas has published a more in-depth online biography of Post, Texas at http://www.tsha.utexas.edu/handbook/online/search.html

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists blueprints of residential homes, commercial and agricultural structures, miscellaneous buildings and structures for the city of Post, Texas. The materials were donated along with the Double U Ranch records.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: The subject headings used by the Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library are derived from the Library of Congress and/or locally developed.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: City of Post, Texas, Blueprint Collection, 1908-1915 and undated, Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, Texas

bibliography.head: Additional Sources
bibliography.bibref: Didway, Charles, ed. A History of Garza County. Seagraves, Texas: Pioneer, 1973.
Eaves, Charles Dudley and C.A. Hutchinson. Post City, Texas: C.W. Post's Colonizing Activities in West Texas. Austin: Texas State Historical Association, 1952.
Macik, Gregory S. What Makes Main Street?: a Study of the Main Street Programs in Plainview, Post, and Littlefield, Texas. Thesis (M. of Arch.)--Texas Tech University, 1994.

relatedmaterial.p: For related materials located in the Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, see the following collections:
